property.name: text
property.value: Look inside the ModalModel to see how this is implemented.

svg.text:
This is a modified version of the Newton's cradle demo, which needs to handle a nondeterministic state machine to get the correct model's behavior.
The key difference between this model and the normal Newton's cradle demo is the initial states of the balls. In this demo, all balls reside at their equilibrium points initially. Ball #1 and ball #2 have non-zero initial velocities, 0.3 and 0.2. Ball #3 has its initial velocity as 0.0.
With these initial settings, the state machine becomes nondeterministic because there are multiple transitions enabled at the start of the simulation (at time 0.0). The interesting thing about this demo is that the behaviors of the balls do not change even with a nondeterministic order of executions of the enabled transitions. Look inside the modal model to see more detailed explanation.
This class defines the dynamics of a pendulum.

At time 0.0, both outgoing transitions of the "state" state are enabled with the initial settings. In particular, theta_1_dot (0.3) > theta_2_dot (0.2) > theta_3_dot (0.0), x_1 + diameter) == x_2, and x_2 + diameter) == x_3. This makes this state machine nondeterministic. However, the order of the executions of these enabled transitiosn do not change the model's behavior. In fact, there is one and only one behavior.
Suppose we execute Transition 1 first, the result is theta_1_dot = 0.2 and theta_2_dot = 0.3. After this, Transition 1 is disabled but Transition 2 is still enabled. After Transition 2 is taken, theta_2_dot = 0.0 and theta_3_dot = 0.3. This makes Transition 1 enabled again, which eventually makes theta_1_dot = 0.0 and theta_2_dot = 0.2. Then, no more transitions are enabled and we achieved a behavior. If we choose to execute Transition 2 first, we will still get the same results. We leave readers an exercise to prove this.
To achieve the unique behavior described above, the outgoing transitions of "state" have to be configured to be nondeterministic (by checking the nondeterministic choice box). The operational semantics of HyVisual will find the unique behavior.

property.name: setActions
